Award.AwardTitle: An investigation on flame-front instability in laminar and turbulent flames

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Combustion in modern high-performance engines, such as automotive and aircraft engines, occurs at high-pressure turbulent conditions. Engine efficiency and reliability strongly depend on flame dynamics, which can be intrinsically unstable in such extreme conditions. The proposed research will characterize the role of flame-front instabilities on flame propagation in engine-relevant conditions. This knowledge is needed for optimizing modern engines, especially at high pressures and high turbulent conditions. Using a unique dual-chamber vessel, which allows high-pressure investigations, the experiments will be targeted to extend our current knowledge on flame-front instabilities in both laminar and turbulent flames. Results from this study can be extended to other problems, such as large-scale fire-whirl dynamics in wildland and urbane fires, which are intrinsically turbulent even the combustion is at atmospheric pressure, in addition to the astrophysical phenomena of the supernova explosion with cosmic intensity. This project will engage graduate and undergraduate students who will be exposed to advanced diagnostics while studying the basic combustion physics and chemistry.

The proposed program aims to understand and quantify the fundamental dynamics of different modes of intrinsic flame-front instabilities of propagating flames in either quiescent or well-defined turbulent environments. Such an understanding is rather immature at present but is required for the further advance in the design and optimization of modern combustion engines. The investigation includes experimentation on spark-ignited, spherical flames at high- and constant-pressure conditions using high-speed high-resolution optical diagnostics. The uniqueness of this study is the well-controlled, well-characterized, high-pressure environment. In such environments, prominent hydrodynamic cellular/wrinkling flame-front structures are manifested and can be precisely quantified using optical diagnostics in unprecedented details. The understanding is facilitated by acquiring high-fidelity experimental data and by quantitatively defining and assessing various stability parameters. This work will characterize global and local length scales for different modes of flame propagation under conditions of isolated instability, isolated turbulence, and their coupled influences. Since the proposed study includes both experimental and theoretical investigations, it will provide the essential synergistic experience in the design and data interpretation of both components, leading to advances in the knowledge of high-pressure turbulent combustion systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This three-year research program studied the propagation and acceleration of flames in the presence of the intrinsic cellular flamefront instabilities, for the understanding and modeling of combustion processes especially those in high-pressure environments. The investigation involved experimentation on spherical flames under high- and constant-pressure conditions, aiming to acquire experimental data of high fidelity in order to quantitatively define the various stability parameters and boundaries of the instability modes. Consequently, the major goals of the projects were to determine the local flamefront statistics as functions of the physics-controlling parameters, such as the Peclet number, thermal expansion ratio, and to determine the effects of such instabilities on the evolution of flame geometry and flow adjacent to the flamefront. Below we discuss three key outcomes of the program in the lights of Intellectual Merits and Broader Impacts.

Intellectual Merits

The study explored the strain rate and curvature statistics in cellularly unstable expanding laminar flames as they evolve through three-stages of the propagations. Detailed analysis of the data show that the mean curvature of such flames is controlled by the flame radius, and the pdf is biased towards higher negative values due to the formation of corners through Huygens propagation. On the other hand, normal mean strain rate increases and shows a three-stage behavior just like the global propagation speed. The study also investigated the possibility of ?self-turbulization? by assessing the flow statistics generated by cellularly unstable flames propagating in a a quiescent environment. It was found that the energy spectra of the tangential velocity along the flame edge follow a power law scaling relation, whose exponent becomes insensitive to flame radius or Peclet number. Interestingly, the same energy spectra for the cellularly unstable flames propagating in turbulent flows show two different behaviors in that, at small wavenumbers the spectra show scaling relations similar to pure turbulent flames, while at large wavenumbers the spectra show scaling relations similar to pure cellular instability.

Broader Impact

Flamefront instability is unavoidable in high-pressure flames, specifically in practical applications such as those within internal combustion reciprocating engines and gas turbines. To model the burning characteristics in these complex high-pressure systems, in which the interplay of turbulence, instability and chemistry are omnipresent, fundamental understanding of each of the building blocks is critical. Our study suggests that the cellularly unstable expanding flame, even in the absence of turbulence, can accelerate almost at a fixed rate irrespective of the pressure. We also showed that the local statistics of such flames can be non-trivial, which is critical in developing reduced-order models for simulations.

Determination of the role of flamefront instability on flame propagation is an important and realistic problem in high-pressure turbulent combustors, such as IC engines and gas turbines. Our results provide a detailed view of local interaction between flamefront and hydrodynamics which controls the global propagation. The high-fidelity measurements obtained in this study is critical in (1) understanding the physical process and (2) preparing benchmark data set for simulations to be validated with. scaling analysis of cellular instability and turbulence interaction and identify a regime diagram. Furthermore, these results are useful in understanding the basic physics of turbulent combustion with flame front instability and developing new models for simulations such as the flame surface density model.
